Data Visualization

Author

Milan Bhardwaj, Matr. Nr. 562289

1 First Challenge

1.1 Goal: Map the time course of the cumulative Covid-19 cases!

library(tidyverse)
#> ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
#> ✔ dplyr     1.1.2     ✔ readr     2.1.4
#> ✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
#> ✔ ggplot2   3.4.2     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
#> ✔ lubridate 1.9.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
#> ✔ purrr     1.0.1     
#> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
#> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
#> ✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
#> ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors
covid_data <- read_csv("https://covid.ourworldindata.org/data/owid-covid-data.csv")
#> Rows: 394167 Columns: 67
#> ── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
#> Delimiter: ","
#> chr   (4): iso_code, continent, location, tests_units
#> dbl  (62): total_cases, new_cases, new_cases_smoothed, total_deaths, new_dea...
#> date  (1): date
#> 
#> ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
#> ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.
countries <- covid_data %>%
  group_by(location) %>% 
  group_split(.keep = TRUE)

1.2 Filter

filter <- c("Germany", "India", "Netherlands", "Canada", "Australia")

getCountry <- function(x, country){
  countries_select <- data.frame()
  for(i in 1:length(x)){
    if(x[[i]]$location[[1]] %in% country){
      return (x[[i]])
    } else {
      next
    }
  }
  return (countries_select)
}

1.3 Calling function for individual countries

res <- 
  getCountry(countries, c("Germany")) %>% 
  rbind(getCountry(countries, c("India"))) %>% 
  rbind(getCountry(countries, c("Netherlands"))) %>% 
  rbind(getCountry(countries, c("Canada"))) %>% 
  rbind(getCountry(countries, c("Australia")))

1.4 Visualization

library(viridis)

res %>% 
  ggplot(aes(date, total_cases, color = location))+
  
  geom_line(linewidth = 0.5) + 
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "bottom",
  ) + 
  
  labs(
    title = "cases by country",
    x = "year",
    y = "sum",
    color = "Country",
  )
#> Warning: Removed 162 rows containing missing values (`geom_line()`).

2 Second Challenge

2.1 Goal: Visualize the distribution of the mortality rate (deaths / population)

covid_data <- read_csv("https://covid.ourworldindata.org/data/owid-covid-data.csv")
#> Rows: 394167 Columns: 67
#> ── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
#> Delimiter: ","
#> chr   (4): iso_code, continent, location, tests_units
#> dbl  (62): total_cases, new_cases, new_cases_smoothed, total_deaths, new_dea...
#> date  (1): date
#> 
#> ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
#> ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

2.2 Data Segregation

data <- covid_data %>% 
  select(location, total_deaths) %>% 
  group_by(location) %>% 
  slice_max(order_by = total_deaths, n = 1) %>% 
  mutate(location = case_when(
    
    location == "India" ~ "India",
    location == "Germany" ~ "Germany",
    location == "Canada" ~ "Canada",
    TRUE ~ location
    
  )) %>%
  distinct()

2.3 Longitudinal and lateral data

world <- map_data("world")

2.4 Final Plot

final_plot <- ggplot() +
  geom_map(data = world, map = world,
           aes(x = long, y = lat, group = group, map_id=region),
           fill = "white", colour = "#7f7f7f", linewidth = 0.5) +
  
  geom_map(data = data, map=world,
           aes(fill=total_deaths, map_id=location, color = total_deaths),
           colour="#7f7f7f", linewidth=0.5) +
  
  scale_fill_continuous(low="red", high="black", guide="colorbar") +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks=c()) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks=c()) +
  labs(title="Covid Deaths", fill="Scale") +
  theme_bw()
#> Warning in geom_map(data = world, map = world, aes(x = long, y = lat, group =
#> group, : Ignoring unknown aesthetics: x and y
final_plot
